WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 430 November 1980 "OUTPUT AND EMPLOYMENT CHANGES IN A "TRADE SENSITIVE" SECTOR: ADJUSTMENT IN THE U.S. FOOTWEAR INDUSTRY" This work in progress report is part of an inquiry being undertaken by the World Bank in conjunction with scholars from twelve industrial countries into the penetration of the markets of industrial countries by exports of manufactures from developing countries. The project seeks to establish the shares of industrial country markets held by the developing countries, changes in such shares in the 1970s, and why they vary among industry groups and countries. The aim is to assist developing and industrial countries to improve their policies through a better understanding of trade patterns and protectionist pressures. The purpose of this paper is to simulate output and employment changes that occur in the United States footwear industry over the next decade under various economic and commercial policy scenarios. The nonrubber footwear industry is portrayed as a "senile" industry with declining output and employment, a simple labor-intensive techno- logy, and aging plant and equipment. Using a dynamic, simultaneous equation model of industry adjustment which includes the interaction of foreign variables, the simulations indicate that even with government intervention and favorable economic growth in the United States, industry output and employment face a long term decline. Footwear production appears to be going through a difficult transition of migration to certain developing countries. Prepared by: John H.  OUTPUT AND MPLOYMNT CHANGES IN A "TRADE SENSITIVE" SECTOR: ADJUSTMENT IN THE U.S. FOOTWEAR INDUSTRY I. 'Introduction "The United States International Trade Commission (ITC) today reported to President Carter that the domestic'footwear industry is being seriously injured by imports and recommended that tariff rate quotas be imposed to relieve the injury. The injury determination was unanimous and relief would last for 5 years allowing the existing quotas of shoes to enter at present duties (6-15%) and "overquota" imports to enter at a 40% tariff rate." 1 Such proclamations from official trade bodies seem to have become a growing part of international commerce in' recent years The shoe industry in the United States is a particularly interesting case, as it is a perennial recipient of import competition and government assis- tance. It is a classic' example of a"senile" industry with declining output and employment, aging plants, and an unsophisticated labor intensive technology, remaining in limbo for over a decade because of various govern- ment measures designed to offset the effect of foreign competition. In this paper we propose first to present an overview of the U.S. nonrubber footwear industry and document changes in import penetration that have occurred in the last decade, and second, to develop a model to simulate the output and employment effects on the U.S. nonrubber footwear industry of cnianging economic conditions in the rest of the world.

A recent development in the U.S. footwear industry, not apparent from the data, is the role of certain rubber footwear on the nonrubber footwear sector. Many types of rubber footwear such as waterproof overshoes and rubber boots are not normally considered close substitutes for nonrub- ber footwear. But sneakers (i.e. rubber soled/fabric upper shoes) are close substitutes. A recent fashion trend in the United States has been the widespread acceptance of sneakers for everyday casual use especially among children and young adults. Sales and imports of sneakers have increased dramatically in recent years and must have had a sizeable impact on the nonrubber footwear industry, even though most attention has been paid to nonrubber footwear imports. Domestic sneaker production increased from 81 to 87 million pairs from 1977 to 1978 while imports jumped from 100 million pairs to 207 million pairs. This is a one year increase in import penetration from 55 percent to 70 percent. The major sources of imports of sneakers are Taiwan and the Republic of Korea -- the two nations where the United States negotiated OMA's on nonrubber footwear in 1977. The rapidity with which these countries respond to a changing trade envirorment is simply amazing. Of total footwear exports from Korea in 1977 70 percent were nonrubber and 30 percent were rubber footwear. In 1978 these percentages were reversed6 The decline in the nonrubber footwear industry in the United States over the last decade is not unique to the U.S. Virtually all industralized countries (with the obvious exceptions of Italy and Spain)

This is but one chapter in a continuing drama which is repeated daily with different players and different products throughout the world. The next section of the paper develops a model which simulates the output and employment effects of changing economic conditions in the rest of the world under alternative trade cegimes on the U.S. nonrubber footwear industry. The model has several features. First, it is dynamic in that the output from one year is fed into the following year. A dynamic framework is desirable to trace the annual impact of changing growth rates, productivity, and the stag- ing of tariffs over an extended period. Second, foreign influences such as productivity growth and other economic variables are incorporated in four simultaneous equations. Finally, simulations are extended over a ten year period in the absence of restrictions on footwear imports and in the presence of the proposed ITC tariff-quota.7 III. V. Output Simulations With and Without Government Intervention Based on the parameter estimates above, the model is simulated for the case of no government intervention in the economy, and then again allowing for a recent proposal by the International Trade Commission to introduce a policy of sharply increased tariffs on imports above a certain level. The basic scenario assumes that U.S. real growth will continue at the same rate over the next decade as was experienced over the past decade, that is at 3.2 percent per annum. Obviously, if the U.S. growth rate falls due say to energy constraints, prospects for any single industry such as footwear will be less favorable, while any acceleration in the growth rate due, for example, to an improving investment climate, will improve its prospects. With respect to rising costs of production in the United States and abroad, and any offsetting productivity gains, there are several ways to allow for these interrelated factors. One possibility is to assume that input cost increases occur at the same rate in the United States as abroad, but that pro- ductivity in the shoe industry increases at a faster rate abroad than in the United States. More rapid foreign productivity increases might occur because
 - 12 - of the faster rate of increase in foreign output, implying that a larger percentage of foreign output will be produced with newer. more efficient machinery. Another way of viewing the process is to assume that any productivity changes are comparable in the U.S. and foreign shoe industries-, but to allow for 14 different rates of cost increase in the United States and abroad,. This scenario corresponds to the suggestion that the United States is pricing itself out of the shoe market because U,.S. wages rise over time while the wages paid by foreign suppliers remain fairly constant due to the availability of a low wage pool of workers. The simulations include two different sets of values with respect to relative productivities and input cost changes. In the first case, foreign productivity is assumed to increase twice as quickly as in the United States, with Input costs ris-ing at the same annual rate of eight percent. The numerical results derived are equivalent.to those which would be obtained if product-ivity changes.were assumed to be comparable, but U.-S. footwear production costs rose a .third again as quickly as abroad. At the end of the decade, the secular decline in employment will range from 10 percent to 28 percent of the footwear labor force. These figures are for the industry as a whole and ignore the fact that some firms (the large ones) will expand due to distribution economies and the ability to respond quickly to design changes, while some will cease to operate The magnitudes of these adjustments demonstrate why the footwear industry has a strong incentive to lobby for some form of protection from foreign competition. The remedy proposed by three of the six ITC commissioners, following the 1977 finding of injury by foreign competition, was that up to 265 million pairs of shoes be allowed to enter annually at the current tariff rate of approximately 9 percent, but that all imports above this level should be dutiable at the rate of 40 percent. This rate would be in effect for the first three years, and then would fall to 30 percent in the fourth year, 20 percent in the fifth year, and be eliminated in the sixth year. Since footwear imports in 1976 were 370 million pairs, the effect of the proposal clearly is to reduce imports. However, to project how much they will be reduced we must ask, refering to Figure 3, whether the additional tariff leads to a potential price greater than or less than Pm, the price which would be consistent with imports of exactly 265 million pairs of shoes. If the 40 percent tariff leads to a potential price greater than im, then imports will not fall below 265 million pairs, since the tariff is not effective at that level of imports, but the price will rise to 'Pm. Alternatively, if the 40 percent tariff results in a price rise less than im, then imports will not fall to 265 million pairs, and some additional tariff revenue will be collected.

 - 16 - Because of growth in income and changes in productivity in each succeeding year, the effect of the quota-tariff policy must be assessed in the dynamic framework already developed. The tariff equivalent of the quota of 265 million pairs of shoes varies over time, but whether this variation is important or not depends upon whether the quota is binding and the additional tariff inoperative, or whether the additional tariff is operative and imports exceed the quota level. We might expect that the quota is binding initially since the desired reduction in imports can be achieved with a rise in price smaller than that which would,result under a 40 percent tariff. However, as demand expands over time and imports become relatively cheaper due to greater foreign productivity changes, imports probably will rise above the quota level since the size tariff necessary to restrict imports to 265 million pairs of shoes will be greater than 40 percent. The results from this policy of government intervention are given in Table 3, also. They demonstrate that the policy will have a significant effect in retarding the decline of domestic employment, due to the expansion which occurs in the first five years. Because the demand for imports is price responsive, the over-quota tariff is not operative in the first three years, and imports exceed the level of 265 million pairs only as the tariff is reduced. As the tariff is phased out, imports rise quite rapidly, and as a consequence the effect on domestic output after ten years is not as favorable as in the very short run. The longer the time horizon chosen, the smaller the difference the short-run policy shift will make. The policy may be characterized as representing a method of buying time, which will not alter very much the long- run prospects of the U.S. shoe industry nor necessarily assist the needed structural adjustment.
 - 17 - Possibly other factors not explicitly considered in the model would justify the policy even in a longer run context. For instance, if the initial favorable spurt in domestic growth allows producers to install more technically advanced equipment than they can under current financial arrangement constraints, perhaps the U.S.-foreign productivity differential will narrow. Alternatively, the ability of other countries to expand output based on low wage labor may be less feasible in the future. However, neither of these two possibilities seems likely to alter the generally unfavorable future projected above. Displacements are avoided in the short run, which may be politically attractive to those holding office now, but no change in the underlying dynamic factors occurs. V. concluding Comae-ts In this paper we have examined the structure of the U.S. nonrubber footwear industry showing how, in the recent decade, it has suffered from increasing import competition. The industry has declined in terms of output, number of firms, and employment, while imports have captured an increasing share of the market. We then quantify some possible future changes in the industry incorporating various international economic variables in a dynamic model of industry output and employment. Using the model various scenarios involving alternative comercial policy and the international variables can be made. For the footwear industry our results do not offer the industry a bright future. Even with government intervention we find a long run decline in industry output and employment. The proposed International Trade Commission quota-tariff policy is merely a temporary solution which simply postpones the adjustment problem rather than addressing it directly.

doc.repnme: Output and employment changes in a "trade sensitive" sector : adjustment in the U.S. footwear industry
doc.abstracts: The purpose of this paper is to simulate output and employment changes that occur in the United States footwear industry over the next decade under various economic and commercial policy scenarios. The nonrubber footwear industry is portrayed as a senile industry with declining output and employment, a simple labor-intensive technology, and aging plant and equipment. Using a dynamic, simultaneous equation model of industry adjustment which includes the interaction of foreign variables, the simulations indicate that even with government intervention and favorable economic growth in the United States, industry output and employment face a long term decline. Footwear production appears to be going through a difficult transition of migration to certain developing countries.
